column4: Has anyone had problems with devices in /dev having incorrect permissions whenever the system is rebooted?
lots of devices with 660, when they should be 664 or 666.
which prevents standard users from flushing stuff to /dev/null or using /dev/random (or /dev/urandom) to seed openssl and create ssh keys.
it ought to be 666 then, unless something chmods it explicitely or you aren't even using udev
yeah I know, it's a fiesty install, I've got about 4 other edgy installs that work fine.
If I change the permissions it's fine, but when I reboot they're back where they were.
what happens to those permissions when you run 'sudo udevtrigger'?
remain what I left them at.
even if you set them to something else first?
they remain what *I* set them to, not what they were on boot.
that certainly sounds like udev is utterly broken.
I was afraid that was going to be the answer.
do you have a tmpfs mounted on /dev?
and someone just starting using the server, damn. Thanks for your help.
